table.name: artefact
table.remarks: Every virtual manuscript is made up from artefacts. The artefact is a polygon region of an image which the editor deems to constitute a coherent piece of material (different editors may come to different conclusions on what makes up an artefact). This may correspond to what the editors of an editio princeps have designated a “fragment”, but often may not, since the columns and fragments in those publications are often made up of joins of various types. Joined fragments should not, as a rule, be defined as a single artefact within the SQE system. Rather, each component of a join should be a separate artefact, and those artefacts can then be positioned properly with each other via the artefact_position table.

table.name: artefact_data
table.remarks: This stores metadata about the artefact.

column.name: name
column.remarks: This is a human readable designation for the artefact. Multiple artefacts are allowed to share the same name, even in a single manuscript, though this is not advised. The artefact as a distinct entity is made unique by its artefact_id.

table.name: artefact_group
table.remarks: This table holds the abstract IDs for the artefact group. An artefact group consists of a name (see artefact_group_name) and a list of members (see artefact_group_member). It is up to the user to determine what an artefact group is meant to do functionally. Typically we assume that when one member of a group is transformed, all members of the group will also be transformed accordingly. The responsibility for such operations, however, lies downstream from the database (i.e., there are no database triggers involved with artefact groups).

table.name: artefact_group_data
table.remarks: This table stores data pertaining to an artefact group, specifically its name.

column.name: name
column.remarks: This is a human readable designation for the artefact group. Multiple artefact groups are allowed to share the same name, even in a single manuscript, though this is not advised. The artefact group as a distinct entity is made unique by its artefact_group_id.

table.name: artefact_group_member
table.remarks: This table is used to aggregate artefacts into groups. An artefact group consists of a name (see artefact_group_name) and a list of members (see artefact_group_member). It is up to the user to determine what an artefact group is meant to do functionally. Typically we assume that when one member of a group is transformed, all members of the group will also be transformed accordingly. The responsibility for such operations, however, lies downstream from the database (i.e., there are no database triggers involved with artefact groups).

column.name: artefact_group_id
column.remarks: The id of the artefact group to which the artefact belongs.

column.name: artefact_id
column.remarks: The id of the artefact to add to the artefact group.

column.name: artefact_id
column.remarks: The id of the artefact to be positioned on the virtual manuscript.

column.name: z_index
column.remarks: This value can move artefacts up or down in relation to other artefacts in the scroll. That is, it sends an artefact further into the foreground or background.

column.name: scale
column.remarks: Resizing to be applied to the artefact.

column.name: rotate
column.remarks: Rotation to be applied to the artefact.

column.name: translate_x
column.remarks: Translation of the artefact on the horizontal axis.

column.name: translate_y
column.remarks: Translation of the artefact on the vertical axis.

column.name: translate_x_non_null
column.remarks: This is a generated column for the sake of uniqueness constraints. It reads the highest possible value of an int instead of NULL, since that value is basically never going to be used (no scroll or manuscript has pages of such a length).

column.name: translate_y_non_null
column.remarks: This is a generated column for the sake of uniqueness constraints. I reads the highest possible value of an int instead of NULL, since that value is basically never going to be used (no scroll or manuscript has pages of such a length).

table.name: artefact_shape
table.remarks: This table holds the polygon describing the region of the artefact in the coordinate system of its image. The image must first be scaled to the PPI defined in manuscript_metrics (1215 PPI by default).

column.name: artefact_id
column.remarks: The id of the artefact to which this shape belongs.

column.name: sqe_image_id
column.remarks: This points to the master image (see SQE_image table) in which this artefact is found.

column.name: region_in_sqe_image
column.remarks: This is the exact polygon of the artefact’s location within the master image’s coordinate system, but alwaya at a resolution of 1215 PPI. If the master image is not 1215 PPI it should be scaled to that resolution before the srtefact is drawn upon it.

column.name: region_in_sqe_image_hash
column.remarks: This is a quick hash of the region_in_sqe_image polygon for the purpose of uniqueness constraints.

table.name: artefact_stack
table.remarks:
This table stores the relationship between artefacts which make up a stack, meaning that they represent parallel layers in a stack. This could be: a) Artefact A is and B represent recto/verso of one layer (artefact), then the layer_A and layer_B must be the same b) A and B represent parts of different layers of a already decomposed stack (reason= ‚found in a stack‘) or as part of wad (reason = ‚part of a wad‘) or as thought by the scholar to belong in the same perimeter of the manuscript (reason=‚reconstructed‘).
The tables allow the creation of a sequence of artefacts: A = recto of layer 1 -> B = verso of layer 1 -> C = recto of recto of layer 2 -> D = verso of layer 2 … (where -> represents a record with the left as artefact_A and the right term as artefact_B)
A special case is marked by shared. We could, e.g., have A as verso and B as recto and additionally a subregion of B as shared to A.

column.name: artefact_A_id
column.remarks: The first artefact in the stack.

column.name: artefact_B_id
column.remarks: The second artefact in the stack.

column.name: artefact_B_offset
column.remarks: Gives the offset by which the artefact B must be moved to match the artefact A. The offset is a POINT geometry.

column.name: layer_A
column.remarks: Gives the number of the layer in the stack to which artefact A belongs. In the case of a recto/verso match, this would be 0. In the case of a wad, a higher number should indicate a layer that is closer to the outside of the scroll, or the front of the codex.

column.name: layer_B
column.remarks: Gives the number of the layer in the stack to which artefact B belongs. In the case of a recto/verso match, this would be 0. In the case of a wad, a higher number should indicate a layer that is closer to the outside of the scroll, or the front of the codex.

column.name: A_is_verso
column.remarks: Boolean whether srtefact A is recto=0 or verso=1.

column.name: B_is_verso
column.remarks: Boolean whether srtefact B is recto=0 or verso=1.

column.name: shared
column.remarks: True if the given region of artefact_B represents a region which appears on the surface of artefact_A (bleeding through, ink glued to the next layer).

table.name: artefact_status
table.remarks: The artefact status is a user definable placeholder to store information about how state of work on defining the artefact.

table.name: attribute
table.remarks: This table stores attributes that can be used to describe a sign_interpretation. They are used in conjunction with a string value in the attribute_value, and any related numeric value can be added in the numeric_value column of the sign_interpretation_attribute table.

column.name: name
column.remarks: Designation of the attribute.

column.name: description
column.remarks: A concise description of the nature of the attribute.

table.name: attribute_value
table.remarks: The specific string value associated with an attribute to describe some aspect of a sign_interpretation.

column.name: attribute_id
column.remarks: The id of the attribute to which a string value is to be assigned.

column.name: string_value
column.remarks: A unique string value that can be applied as an attribute to a sign interpretation.

column.name: description
column.remarks: A concise description of the attribute value.

table.name: attribute_value_css
table.remarks: Custom CSS to be applied to and attribute when it is visualized in an HTML context.

column.name: attribute_value_id
column.remarks: The attribute value to be formatted with this CSS code.

column.name: css
column.remarks: The CSS descriptor(s) to apply to sign interpretations with the linked attribute value.

table.name: edition
table.remarks: This table provides the anchor for a complete scholarly edition of a manuscript. It also maintains the locked and public status of the edition.

column.name: edition_id
column.remarks: Unique id of the edition.

column.name: manuscript_id
column.remarks: Id of the manuscript treated in this edition.

column.name: locked
column.remarks: A boolean wheather this edition is locked. If an edition is locked, the SQE_API will not allow any changes to be made to it.

column.name: copyright_holder
column.remarks: This is the person or institution who holds copyright for the edition.

column.name: collaborators
column.remarks: Each edition may have a set list of collaborators. If NULL, then the API will automatically construct a list of collaborators based on the edition_editors.

column.name: public
column.remarks: A boolean signalling whether this edition has been made publicly viewable or not. Public relates only to viewing rights, not to write or admin. As the system is currently constructed all public editions should also be locked.

table.name: edition_editor
table.remarks: Each edition has one or more edition editors, which are the individual users working on that edition. Each edition editor has individual access rights that are specified here.

column.name: edition_editor_id
column.remarks: Id of the editor, who is working on a particular edition.

column.name: user_id
column.remarks: Link to the editor’s user account.

column.name: edition_id
column.remarks: This is the id of the edition on which this editor is working.

column.name: may_write
column.remarks: Boolean whether this editor has permission to write to the edition. An editor must have read permissions to have write permissions.

column.name: may_lock
column.remarks: Boolean whether the editor is allowed to lock the edition.

column.name: may_read
column.remarks: Boolean whether the editor is allowed to read the edition. No editors may ever be deleted from an edition, but revoking read access to an editor is the SQE equivalent to fully removing the editor from work on an edition.

column.name: is_admin
column.remarks: Boolean whether an editor is an admin. An admin must have read permission. Only an admin may change the permissions of other editors, including revoking admin status (including for herself). Each edition must have at least one admin. Only an admin may publish or delete an edition.

table.name: edition_editor_request
table.remarks: This table stores the data for a request for a user to become an editor of an edition. It contains details about the permissions associated with the request.

column.name: token
column.remarks: Unique token the user will provide to verify the requested action.

column.name: admin_user_id
column.remarks: User id of the admin who requested the editor.

column.name: editor_user_id
column.remarks: User id of the editor who was invited to join the edition.

column.name: edition_id
column.remarks: The id of the edition to be shared.

column.name: is_admin
column.remarks: Offering admin rights.

column.name: may_lock
column.remarks: Offering locking rights.

column.name: may_write
column.remarks: Offering write rights.

column.name: date
column.remarks: Date the editor request was sent.

table.name: font_file
table.remarks: Contains a font file to be used for reconstructed text or overlays

column.name: font_name
column.remarks: A human readable name

column.name: is_public
column.remarks: Flag to mark whether the file may be used also by others

column.name: font_binary_data
column.remarks: The font data to be sent as file to the front end

column.name: font_format
column.remarks: The font-format of the font_binary_data

table.name: iaa_edition_catalog
table.remarks: This table contains the IAA data for the editio princeps reference for all of their images.

column.name: manuscript
column.remarks: Standard designation of the manuscript.

column.name: edition_name
column.remarks: Name of the publication in which the editio princeps appears.

column.name: edition_volume
column.remarks: Volume of the publication in which the editio princeps appears.

column.name: edition_location_1
column.remarks: First tier identifier (usually a page number).

column.name: edition_location_2
column.remarks: Second tier identifier (usually a fragment/column designation).

column.name: edition_side
column.remarks: Side designation in editio princeps.

column.name: manuscript_id
column.remarks: Id of the manuscript within the SQE database.

column.name: comment
column.remarks: Extra comments.

table.name: iaa_edition_catalog_to_text_fragment
table.remarks: This is a temporary table to curate matches between the image catalog system and the SQE text fragments in a manuscript. It should eventually be deprecated in favor of matches inferred by spatial overlap on the virtual scroll of a the placement of a ROI linked to text transcription and an artefact linked to an image.

table.name: iaa_edition_catalog_to_text_fragment_confirmation
table.remarks: This table is part of the temporary and preliminary catalog info matching system. There are three possibilities here: 1. confirmed = 0 and user_id IS NULL (the match has neither been confirmed nor rejected); 2. confirmed = 0 and user_id IS NOT NULL (the user with user_id has rejected the match); 3. confirmed = 1 and user_id IS NOT NULL (the user with user_id has confirmed the match as valid). The pairing confirmed = 1 and user_id IS NOT NULL is an invalid combination.

column.name: confirmed
column.remarks: Boolean for whether the match has been confirmed (1) or rejected (0). If this is set to 0 and the user_id is NULL, then the match has neither been confirmed nor rejected (thus it should be queued for review).

column.name: user_id
column.remarks: user_id of the person who has confirmed or rejected the match. If NULL, the match has neither been confirmed nor rejected.

table.name: image_catalog
table.remarks: The referencing system of the institution providing the images.

column.name: institution
column.remarks: Name of the institution providing the image.

column.name: catalog_number_1
column.remarks: First tier object identifier (perhaps a plate or accession number).

column.name: catalog_number_2
column.remarks: Second tier object identifier (if available). Perhaps a fragment number on a plate, or some subdesignation of an accession number.

column.name: catalog_side
column.remarks: Side reference designation, recto = 0, verso = 1.

column.name: object_id
column.remarks: An autogenerated human readable object identifier based on the institution and catalogue numbers.

table.name: image_to_iaa_edition_catalog
table.remarks: Temporary table to link image catalog info with edition info until the SQE_image table is fully populated. Once that table is populated this one will become redundant. This was autogenerated from IAA data.

table.name: image_to_image_map
table.remarks: This table contains the mapping information to correlate images of the same object via linear affine transformations. The mapping may only invlove a portion of either image as defined in the region_on_imageX columns.

column.name: image1_id
column.remarks: Id of the first SQE_image to be mapped.

column.name: image2_id
column.remarks: Id of the second SQE_image to be mapped.

column.name: region_on_image1
column.remarks: Region on image 1 that can be found in image 2.

column.name: region_on_image2
column.remarks: Region in image 2 that can be found in image 1.

column.name: transform_matrix
column.remarks: Linear affine transform to apply to image 2 in order to align it with image 1. The format is: “{“matrix”: [[sx cosθ, -sy sinθ, tx],[sx sinθ, sy cosθ, ty]]}”.

column.name: region1_hash
column.remarks: θ

column.name: region2_hash
column.remarks: Polygon hash for uniqueness constraints.

table.name: image_urls
table.remarks: URL’s for the iiif image servers providing our images.

column.name: url
column.remarks: URL prefix of the iiif server.

column.name: suffix
column.remarks: Special suffux for file name (if applicable). Usually default.jpg.

column.name: proxy
column.remarks: Specify a proxy address if it is necessary to use a proxy for CORS compliance.

column.name: license
column.remarks: License for this iiif servers resources.

table.name: line
table.remarks: The line is an abstract placeholder which can receive definition via the line_data table. It must be nested in a text fragment (text_fragment_to_line) and will contain signs (line_to_sign)

table.name: line_data
table.remarks: Metadata pertaining to the description of a line of transcribed text.

column.name: name
column.remarks: Name designation for this line.

table.name: line_to_sign
table.remarks: Linking of abstract signs to a line.

table.name: main_action
table.remarks: Table recording mutation actions (it can be used for infinite undo). This table stores the state of the action (rewound or not), the date of the change, and the edition that the action is associated with. The table single_action links to the entries here and describes the table in which the action occurred, the id of the entry in that table that was involved, and the nature of the action (creating a connection between that entry and the edition of the main_action, or deleting the connection between that entry and the edition of the main_action).

column.name: time
column.remarks: The time that the database action was performed.

column.name: rewinded
column.remarks: Boolean relaying whether the particular action has been rewound or not.

column.name: edition_editor_id
column.remarks: Id of the editor who performed the action.

column.name: edition_id
column.remarks: Id of the edition in which the action was performed.

table.name: manuscript
table.remarks: The manuscript is an abstract placeholder that is given metadata via the manuscript_data table. This allows multiple editions of the same manuscript to be created, regardless of the naming scheme used. A manuscript will contain one or more text fragments (manuscript_to_text_fragment)

table.name: manuscript_data
table.remarks: Description of a reconstructed manuscript or combination.

column.name: name
column.remarks: Name designation of the manuscript.

table.name: manuscript_metrics
table.remarks: This table stores basic information about the gross metrics of a manuscript. The user is able to specify an x/y-origin point for the start of the manuscript along with its proposed height and width in millimeters. The coordinate system begins top left, positive values increase while moving downward on the y-axis and while moving rightward on the x-axis. The PPI is currently fixed ad 1215 PPI to facilitate comparison of GIS data between manuscripts. All images should be scaled to this resolution before creating artefacts and ROIs that are placed upon the virtual manuscript.

column.name: x_origin
column.remarks: This is the x value of the starting point of the manuscript. The coordinate system begins top left, positive values increase while moving downward on the y-axis and while moving rightward on the x-axis.

column.name: y_origin
column.remarks: This is the y value of the starting point of the manuscript. The coordinate system begins top left, positive values increase while moving downward on the y-axis and while moving rightward on the x-axis.

column.name: width
column.remarks: This is the width of the manucsript in millimeters.

column.name: height
column.remarks: This is the height of the manucsript in millimeters.

column.name: pixels_per_inch
column.remarks: This is the pixels per inch for the manuscript. At the outset we have decided to set all manuscripts at 1215 PPI, which is the resolution of most images being used. All images should be scaled to this resolution before creating artefacts and ROIs that are placed upon the virtual manuscript. We have no plans to use varying PPI settings for different manuscripts, which would slightly complicate GIS calculations across multiple manuscripts.

table.name: manuscript_to_text_fragment
table.remarks: Links an entry in the text_fragment table to a reconstructed manuscript.

table.name: parallel_group
table.remarks: Provides a unique identifier for groups of sign_stream_sections representing parallel chunks of text

column.name: parallel_group_id
column.remarks: Unique identifier

table.name: parallel_group_pair
table.remarks: Creates a pair of parallel_groups

column.name: parallel_group_pair_id
column.remarks: Unique identifier

column.name: parallel_group_a_id
column.remarks: Refers to the first parallel_group

column.name: parallel_group_b_id
column.remarks: Refers to second parallel_group

table.name: parallel_group_pair_to_type
table.remarks: Connexts a parallel_group_pair with a parallel type

column.name: parallel_group_pair_to_type_id
column.remarks: Unique identifier

column.name: parallel_group_pair_id
column.remarks: Refers to a parallel_group_pair

column.name: parallel_type_id
column.remarks: Refers to a parallel_type.

table.name: parallel_sign_stream_section
table.remarks: This table enables a connection to be made between parallel words in two different manuscripts.

column.name: parallel_sign_stream_section_id
column.remarks: Unique identifier

column.name: sign_stream_section_id
column.remarks: Reference to sign_stream_section

column.name: parallel_group_id
column.remarks: Reference to parallel_group

table.name: parallel_type
table.remarks: Hierarchical list which defines parallel_types

column.name: parallel_type_id
column.remarks: Unique identifier

column.name: parent_type_id
column.remarks: Refers to a parent type

column.name: name
column.remarks: Name of the type.

table.name: point_to_point_map
table.remarks: This table holds data pertaining to nonlinear transforms between a set of two images. It stores a list of points in one image and the corresponding points in another image.

column.name: point_on_image1
column.remarks: This is the list of corresponding points for image 1.

column.name: point_on_image2
column.remarks: This is the list of corresponding points for image 2.

table.name: position_in_stream
table.remarks: This table provides ordering data for the transcriptions. It provides a DAG linking sign_interpretations to each other.

column.name: is_main
column.remarks: If true, the next item will be first in the list of next items. There should only one next item marked this way for each item of this owner.

table.name: position_in_stream_to_section_rel
table.remarks: This table links sign_interpretations to the words they are part of. This creates a bridge from the SQE data to the words stored in the QWB database.

column.name: sign_stream_section_id
column.remarks: Reference to sign_stream_section

table.name: position_in_text_fragment_stream
table.remarks: Gives a stream of fragments in a scroll in the right order

column.name: is_main
column.remarks: If true, the next item will be first in the list of next items. There should only one next item marked this way for each item of this owner.

table.name: qwb_ref
table.remarks: This table creates a connection between the references in the QWB database and the textual references within the SQE text system.

column.name: line_id
column.remarks: The SQE line id related to this QWB reference

column.name: qwb_scroll_name
column.remarks: The precise name of the scroll in the QWB database

column.name: qwb_fragment_name
column.remarks: The precise name of the fragment or column in the QWB database

column.name: qwb_line_name
column.remarks: The precise line designation in the QWB database

table.name: recent_edition_catalog_to_col_confirmation
table.viewSql: select `SQE`.`iaa_edition_catalog_to_text_fragment_confirmation`.`iaa_edition_catalog_to_text_fragment_id` AS `iaa_edition_catalog_to_text_fragment_id`,`SQE`.`iaa_edition_catalog_to_text_fragment_confirmation`.`confirmed` AS `confirmed`,`SQE`.`iaa_edition_catalog_to_text_fragment_confirmation`.`user_id` AS `user_id`,max(`SQE`.`iaa_edition_catalog_to_text_fragment_confirmation`.`time`) AS `MAX(``time``)` from `SQE`.`iaa_edition_catalog_to_text_fragment_confirmation` group by `SQE`.`iaa_edition_catalog_to_text_fragment_confirmation`.`iaa_edition_catalog_to_text_fragment_id`

column.name: confirmed
column.remarks: Boolean for whether the match has been confirmed (1) or rejected (0). If this is set to 0 and the user_id is NULL, then the match has neither been confirmed nor rejected (thus it should be queued for review).

column.name: user_id
column.remarks: user_id of the person who has confirmed or rejected the match. If NULL, the match has neither been confirmed nor rejected.

table.name: roi_position
table.remarks: ROI’s are linked to artefacts. To get the location of the ROI in the coordinate system of the “virtual manuscript, one must first apply the roi_position and then the position of the linked artefact. This can by done via the UDF nested_geom_transform.

column.name: artefact_id
column.remarks: ROI’s are linked to artefacts. Those artefacts may be real (i.e., linked to an image) or virtual (i.e., not linked to an image). A virtual manuscript is the sum total of all the artefacts positioned in it.

column.name: translate_x
column.remarks: The translation on the X axis necessary to position the a ROI shape in the artefact's coordinate system. The artefact coordinate system is the same as the “master imafe” to which it is linked, but always scaled to a resolution of 1215 PPI.

column.name: translate_y
column.remarks: The translation on the Y axis necessary to position the a ROI shape in the artefact's coordinate system. The artefact coordinate system is the same as the “master imafe” to which it is linked, but always scaled to a resolution of 1215 PPI.

column.name: stance_rotation
column.remarks: Any rotation that would be necessary for the sign to have the correct stance on a horizontal plane. This is to be applied whent creating fonts and analyzing the expected script orientation in relation to its actual orientation on an artefact.

table.name: roi_shape
table.remarks: This table holds the polygon describing the ROI in its own coordinate system. The roi_position table situates the polygon in the coordinate system of the artefact.

column.name: path
column.remarks: This is a POLYGON geometry describing the shape of the ROI. It is its own 0,0 coordinate system and is correlated with a location in an artefact via a translation (without scale or rotation) in the roi_position table. Its resolution is the same as the artefact, 1215 PPI.

table.name: scribal_font
table.remarks: Defines a font found in the scrolls. It connects to a font file and is referred by glyph info

column.name: scribal_font_id
column.remarks: Unique identifier

column.name: font_file_id
column.remarks: Reference to the font file.

column.name: default_word_space
column.remarks: The default space in pixel to be set between two words

column.name: default_interlinear_space
column.remarks: The default space between two lines in pixel

table.name: scribal_font_glyph_metrics
table.remarks: Contains the bounding box and position metrics of a scribal font. Only used to calculate ROIs not yet set by the user.

column.name: scribal_font_glyph_metrics_id
column.remarks: Unique identifier

column.name: scribal_font_id
column.remarks: Reference to scribal font

column.name: unicode_char
column.remarks: Char of font

column.name: width
column.remarks: Width of glyph

column.name: height
column.remarks: Height of glyph

column.name: y_offset
column.remarks: Vertical offset glyph (thought to stand on line)

table.name: scribal_font_kerning
table.remarks: Contains kerning of glyph of a scribal font. Only used to calculated the position of signs not yet positioned by the user

column.name: scribal_font_kerning_id
column.remarks: Unique identifier

column.name: scribal_font_id
column.remarks: Reference to scribal font

column.name: first_unicode_char
column.remarks: Charcode of the first glyph

column.name: second_unicode_char
column.remarks: Charcode of the second glyph

column.name: kerning_x
column.remarks: Horizontal kerning

column.name: kerning_y
column.remarks: Vertical kerning

table.name: sign
table.remarks: This is an abstract placeholder allowing a multiplicity of interpretations to be related to each other by linking to the same sign_id.

table.name: sign_interpretation
table.remarks: This table describes the interpretation of signs in an edition. Currently this includes both characters, spaces, and formatting marks, it could perhaps also include other elements that one might want to define as a sign.

column.name: sign_id
column.remarks: Id of the sign being described.

column.name: is_variant
column.remarks: Boolean set to true when current entry is a variant interpretation of a sign.

column.name: character
column.remarks: This may be left null for signs that are not interpreted as characters (e.g., control signs like line start/line end or material features of any sort), otherwise it is a single letter.

table.name: sign_interpretation_attribute
table.remarks: This table links sign_interpretations to the attributes that further describe the sign’s interpretation.

column.name: sign_interpretation_id
column.remarks: Id of the sign interpretation being descibed.

column.name: attribute_value_id
column.remarks: Id of the attribute to apply to this sign interpretation.

column.name: sequence
column.remarks: Absolute ordering of this record. This is used to define the order of all records for the same sign_char_id.

column.name: numeric_value
column.remarks: Contains the width of a character (normally 1), space (dto.), or vacat (normally > 1) or the level of probability.

table.name: sign_interpretation_commentary
table.remarks: This table allows editors to attach commentary to a specific attribute of a sign interpretation.

column.name: sign_interpretation_id
column.remarks: Id of the sign interpretation being commented on.

column.name: attribute_id
column.remarks: Id of the attrivute describing the aspect of this sign interpretation being commented on.

column.name: commentary
column.remarks: Editorial comments.

table.name: sign_interpretation_roi
table.remarks: This table links a sign_interpretation to the ROI or ROIs it describes.

column.name: sign_interpretation_id
column.remarks: Id of the sign interpretation being marked in an artefact.

column.name: roi_shape_id
column.remarks: Id of the shape for this ROI.

column.name: roi_position_id
column.remarks: Id for the position of this ROI in its artefact.

column.name: exceptional
column.remarks: Boolean whether this ROI is exceptional (and thus should be excluded from some statistical analyses).

table.name: sign_stream_section
table.remarks: A collection of coherent signs from a stream.

column.name: sign_stream_section_id
column.remarks: Unique identifier

table.name: sign_stream_section_to_qwb_word
table.remarks: Provides n:m connection between qwb words and sections of the sign stream.

column.name: sign_stream_section_id
column.remarks: Refers to sign_stream_section

column.name: qwb_word_id
column.remarks: Refers to qwb_word

table.name: single_action
table.remarks: This table joins with the main_action table to record all mutation actions taken regarding each edition.

column.name: main_action_id
column.remarks: Id of the main action that this single action belongs to.

column.name: action
column.remarks: The nature of the action applied. A link to an edition was either added or deleted.

column.name: table
column.remarks: Table containing the entry that was either added to or deleted from the edition.

column.name: id_in_table
column.remarks: Id of the record that was added to or deleted from the edition (of the linked main_action) in the “table”_owner table.

table.name: SQE_image
table.remarks: This table defines an image. It contains referencing data to access the image via iiif servers, it also stores metadata relating to the image itself, such as sizing, resolution, image color range, etc. It also maintains a link to the institutional referencing system, and the referencing of the editio princeps (as provided by the imaging institution).

column.name: image_urls_id
column.remarks: Link to image_urls table which contains the url of the iiif server that provides this image and the default suffix used to get images from that server.

column.name: filename
column.remarks: Actual filename of the image as specified on the iiif server. This may often look more like a URI, or a partial URI.

column.name: native_width
column.remarks: We store internally the pixel width of the full size image.

column.name: native_height
column.remarks: We store internally the pixel height of the full size image.

column.name: dpi
column.remarks: The DPI of the full size image (used to calculate relative scaling of images). This should be calculated as optimally as possible and should not rely on EXIF data.

column.name: type
column.remarks: Four values: Color = 0 Grayscale = 1 Raking light right = 2 Raking light left = 4 Perhaps remove in favor of “wavelength_start" and “wavelength_end”.

column.name: wavelength_start
column.remarks: Starting wavelength of image in nanometers.

column.name: wavelength_end
column.remarks: Ending wavelength of image in nanometers.

column.name: is_master
column.remarks: Boolean determining if the image is a “master image”. Since we have multiple images of each fragment, one image is designated as the master (generally the full color image), all others are non master images and will have a corresponding entry in “image_to_image_map” which provides and transforms (translate, scale, rotate) necessary to line the two images up with each other.

column.name: image_catalog_id
column.remarks: Id of the image in the image catalogue.

column.name: is_recto
column.remarks: Notes wether the original image is thought to show rect0 (1) or verso (0) of the fragment. This can be taken as default value for recto/verso-relation in artefact_stack

table.name: text_fragment
table.remarks: The text_fragment is an abstract placeholder that can be named via text_fragment_data, subsumed in a manuscript (manuscript_to_text_fragment), and joined with the lines that contitute it (text_fragment_to_line).

table.name: text_fragment_data
table.remarks: This table defines the properties of a unified grouping of text containing one or more lines.

column.name: name
column.remarks: Name designation for this fragment of text (usually col. x or frg. x).

table.name: text_fragment_to_line
table.remarks: This table links lines of an edition to a specific text fragment.

table.name: user
table.remarks:
This table stores the data of all registered users, Created by Martin 17/03/03
The email is the unique identifier for each user (i.d., the username).

column.name: email
column.remarks: The user account email is used as the unique identifier for the account. Users authenticate with a correct email + password.

column.name: pw
column.remarks: A hashed password

column.name: forename
column.remarks: The user's forename, may be null. Neither forename or surname are unique (separately or combined)

column.name: surname
column.remarks: The user's surname, may be null. Neither forename or surname are unique (separately or combined)

column.name: organization
column.remarks: The user's current organization, may be null.

column.name: activated
column.remarks: Boolean for whether a user has authenticaed registration via the emailed token.

table.name: user_contributions
table.remarks: Created by Martin 17/03/29

table.name: user_email_token
table.remarks: This table holds a list of unique tokens that are sent to the user in order to confirm certain operations in the database. These tokens are intended to expire and a scheduled event in the database clears out all entries that are over 2 days old.

column.name: token
column.remarks: Unique token the user will provide to verify the requested action.

column.name: type
column.remarks: The type of action permitted with the specified token.

column.name: date_created
column.remarks: Date the token was created or updated. This is used by an event that clears out all entries from this table that are older than 2 days.

table.name: work_status
table.remarks: This table stores user-definable work status messages that can be applied to various data tables. They are used to indicate the current status of editor curation for the data entry.

column.name: work_status_message
column.remarks: A status message on the ccurrent state of work.

routine.name: SPLIT_STRING
routine.definition: RETURN REPLACE(SUBSTRING(SUBSTRING_INDEX(x, delim, pos), LENGTH(SUBSTRING_INDEX(x, delim, pos -1)) + 1), delim, '')

routine.name: add_commentary
cursor_proc
getCatalogAndEdition
routine.definition: select image_catalog.image_catalog_id, edition_catalog.edition_catalog_id from image_catalog left join image_to_edition_catalog USING(image_catalog_id) left join edition_catalog USING(edition_catalog_id) where image_catalog.catalog_number_1 = param_plate AND image_catalog.catalog_number_2 = param_fragment AND image_catalog.catalog_side = param_side

routine.name: getMasterImageListings
routine.definition: select edition_catalog.composition, image_catalog.institution, image_catalog.catalog_number_1, image_catalog.catalog_number_2, edition_catalog.edition_name, edition_catalog.edition_volume, edition_catalog.edition_location_1, edition_catalog.edition_location_2, SQE_image.sqe_image_id from SQE_image left join image_catalog USING(image_catalog_id) left join edition_catalog USING(edition_catalog_id) where SQE_image.is_master=1 AND image_catalog.catalog_side=0 order by edition_catalog.composition

routine.name: getScrollArtefacts
routine.definition: SELECT distinct artefact.artefact_id as id, ST_AsText(ST_Envelope(artefact.region_in_master_image)) as rect, ST_AsText(artefact.region_in_master_image) as poly, ST_AsText(artefact.position_in_scroll) as pos, image_urls.url as url, image_urls.suffix as suffix, SQE_image.filename as filename, SQE_image.dpi as dpi from artefact inner join SQE_image USING(sqe_image_id) inner join image_urls USING(image_urls_id) inner join image_to_edition_catalog USING(image_catalog_id) inner join edition_catalog_to_discrete_reference USING(edition_catalog_id) inner join discrete_canonical_reference USING(discrete_canonical_reference_id) inner join scroll USING(scroll_id) inner join edition_catalog USING(edition_catalog_id) where scroll.scroll_id=scroll_id and edition_catalog.edition_side=side

routine.name: getScrollDimensions
routine.definition: select artefact_id, MAX(JSON_EXTRACT(transform_matrix, '$.matrix[0][2]') + ((ST_X(ST_PointN(ST_ExteriorRing(ST_ENVELOPE(region_in_sqe_image)), 2)) - ST_X(ST_PointN(ST_ExteriorRing(ST_ENVELOPE(region_in_sqe_image)), 1))) * (1215 / SQE_image.dpi))) as max_x, MAX(JSON_EXTRACT(transform_matrix, '$.matrix[1][2]') + ((ST_Y(ST_PointN(ST_ExteriorRing(ST_ENVELOPE(region_in_sqe_image)), 3)) - ST_Y(ST_PointN(ST_ExteriorRing(ST_ENVELOPE(region_in_sqe_image)), 1))) * (1215 / SQE_image.dpi))) as max_y from artefact_position join artefact_position_owner using(artefact_position_id) join artefact_shape using(artefact_id) join artefact_shape_owner using(artefact_shape_id) join SQE_image USING(sqe_image_id) join image_catalog using(image_catalog_id) where artefact_position.scroll_id=scroll_id_num and artefact_position_owner.scroll_version_id = version_id and artefact_shape_owner.scroll_version_id = version_id and image_catalog.catalog_side=0

routine.name: getScrollHeight
routine.definition: select artefact_id, MAX(JSON_EXTRACT(transform_matrix, '$.matrix[1][2]') + ((ST_Y(ST_PointN(ST_ExteriorRing(ST_ENVELOPE(region_in_sqe_image)), 3)) - ST_Y(ST_PointN(ST_ExteriorRing(ST_ENVELOPE(region_in_sqe_image)), 1))) * (1215 / SQE_image.dpi))) as max_y from artefact_position join artefact_position_owner using(artefact_position_id) join artefact_shape using(artefact_id) join artefact_shape_owner using(artefact_shape_id) join SQE_image USING(sqe_image_id) join image_catalog using(image_catalog_id) where artefact_position.scroll_id=scroll_id_num and artefact_position_owner.scroll_version_id = version_id and artefact_shape_owner.scroll_version_id = version_id and image_catalog.catalog_side=0

routine.name: getScrollVersionArtefacts
routine.definition: SELECT distinct artefact.artefact_id as id, ST_AsText(ST_Envelope(artefact.region_in_master_image)) as rect, ST_AsText(artefact.region_in_master_image) as poly, ST_AsText(artefact.position_in_scroll) as pos, image_urls.url as url, image_urls.suffix as suffix, SQE_image.filename as filename, SQE_image.dpi as dpi, artefact.rotation as rotation from artefact_owner join artefact using(artefact_id) join scroll_version using(scroll_version_id) inner join SQE_image USING(sqe_image_id) inner join image_urls USING(image_urls_id) inner join image_catalog using(image_catalog_id) where artefact.scroll_id=scroll_id_num and artefact_owner.scroll_version_id = version_id and image_catalog.catalog_side=0

routine.name: getScrollWidth
routine.definition: select artefact_id, MAX(JSON_EXTRACT(transform_matrix, '$.matrix[0][2]') + ((ST_X(ST_PointN(ST_ExteriorRing(ST_ENVELOPE(region_in_sqe_image)), 2)) - ST_X(ST_PointN(ST_ExteriorRing(ST_ENVELOPE(region_in_sqe_image)), 1))) * (1215 / SQE_image.dpi))) as max_x from artefact_position join artefact_position_owner using(artefact_position_id) join artefact_shape using(artefact_id) join artefact_shape_owner using(artefact_shape_id) join SQE_image USING(sqe_image_id) join image_catalog using(image_catalog_id) where artefact_position.scroll_id=scroll_id_num and artefact_position_owner.scroll_version_id = version_id and artefact_shape_owner.scroll_version_id = version_id and image_catalog.catalog_side=0

routine.name: get_fragment
get_fragment_text
get_line_text
get_line_text_html
get_scroll
get_sign_json
routine.definition:
BEGIN
	SET @output_text ='';
	SET @is_last = 0;
	SET @next_id_var=next_id_var;
	
	PREPARE stm FROM 
		"SELECT 
			IF(sign.sign_type_id=9, @output_text,
			CONCAT_WS('',@output_text,
					'{""SIGN_ID"":',sign.sign_id,', ',
					'""SIGN"":""',if(sign.sign like '',' ', sign.sign),'"", ', 
					'""SIGN_TYPE"":""', sign_type.type,'"", ',
					'""SIGN_WIDTH"":', sign.width ,', ',
					'""MIGHT_BE_WIDER"":', if(might_be_wider, 'true', 'false') ,', ',
					'""READABILITY"":""', sign.readability,'"", ',
					'""IS_RECONSTRUCTED"":',if(is_reconstructed, 'true', 'false') ,', ',
					'""IS_RETRACED"":',if(is_retraced, 'true', 'false') ,', ',
					'""CORRECTION"":', set_to_json_array(sign.correction) ,', ',
					'""RELATIVE_POSITION"":[', (select 
							CONCAT('""',GROUP_CONCAT(sign_relative_position.`type` ORDER BY LEVEL ASC SEPARATOR '"",""'),
								 '""')
							FROM sign_relative_position
							WHERE sign_relative_position.sign_relative_position_id=sign.sign_id), 
					']},')), 
			position_in_stream.next_sign_id,
			IFNULL(FIND_IN_SET('LINE_END',sign.break_type),0)
			INTO  @output_text, @next_id_var, @is_last	
			FROM sign
			JOIN position_in_stream ON position_in_stream.sign_id=sign.sign_id
			JOIN sign_type ON sign_type.sign_type_id=sign.sign_type_id
			WHERE sign.sign_id=?";
			
	WHILE @is_last = 0   DO
		EXECUTE stm USING @next_id_var;
	END WHILE;
	DEALLOCATE PREPARE stm;
	SET full_output = concat(full_output, SUBSTRING(@output_text, 1, CHAR_LENGTH(@output_text)-1));
END

routine.name: nyewe2w234556
routine.definition:
BEGIN
	SET @output_text ='';
	SET @is_last = 0;
	SET @next_id_var=next_id_var;
	
	PREPARE stm FROM 
		"SELECT 
			IF(sign.sign_type_id=9, @output_text,
			CONCAT_WS('',@output_text,
					'<span class=QWB_SIGN',
					IF(FIND_IN_SET('OVERWRITTEN', sign.correction)>0, ' QWB_OVERWRITTEN', ''),
					IF(FIND_IN_SET('ERASED', sign.correction)>0, ' QWB_ERASED', ''),
					IF(sign.is_reconstructed=1, ' QWB_RECONSTRUCTED', ''),
					IF(sign.is_reconstructed=1, ' QWB_RECONSTRUCTED', ''),
					



sign.sign_id,', ',
					'""SIGN"":""',if(sign.sign like '',' ', sign.sign),'"", ', 
					'""SIGN_TYPE"":""', sign_type.type,'"", ',
					'""SIGN_WIDTH"":', sign.width ,', ',
					'""MIGHT_BE_WIDER"":', if(might_be_wider, 'true', 'false') ,', ',
					'""READABILITY"":""', sign.readability,'"", ',
					'""IS_RECONSTRUCTED"":',if(is_reconstructed, 'true', 'false') ,', ',
					'""IS_RETRACED"":',if(is_retraced, 'true', 'false') ,', ',
					'""CORRECTION"":', set_to_json_array(sign.correction) ,', ',
					'""RELATIVE_POSITION"":[', (select 
							CONCAT('""',GROUP_CONCAT(sign_relative_position.`type` ORDER BY LEVEL ASC SEPARATOR '"",""'),
								 '""')
							FROM sign_relative_position
							WHERE sign_relative_position.sign_relative_position_id=sign.sign_id), 
					']},')), 
			position_in_stream.next_sign_id,
			IFNULL(FIND_IN_SET('LINE_END',sign.break_type),0)
			INTO  @output_text, @next_id_var, @is_last	
			FROM sign
			JOIN position_in_stream ON position_in_stream.sign_id=sign.sign_id
			JOIN sign_type ON sign_type.sign_type_id=sign.sign_type_id
			WHERE sign.sign_id=?";
			
	WHILE @is_last = 0   DO
		EXECUTE stm USING @next_id_var;
	END WHILE;
	DEALLOCATE PREPARE stm;
	SET full_output = concat(full_output, SUBSTRING(@output_text, 1, CHAR_LENGTH(@output_text)-1));
END

routine.name: set_to_json_array
